claim: If you type your PIN number backwards at an ATM, a notification will be sent to the police.

supporting.text: There is no widely documented evidence or official confirmation from banks or law enforcement agencies that ATMs are programmed to send notifications to the police when a PIN is entered backwards.

attacks.text: There is no widely documented evidence or official confirmation from banks or law enforcement agencies that ATMs are programmed to send notifications to the police when a PIN is entered backwards.
Some ATMs may have security features that detect unusual PIN entry patterns, including reversed PINs, and could trigger alerts to authorities.
Even if ATMs detect unusual PIN patterns, there is no standard protocol for notifying police, as this would overwhelm law enforcement with false alarms.
Urban legends and anecdotal reports suggest that some ATMs might have this feature, indicating possible undocumented implementations.
Anecdotal reports are unreliable and lack verifiable evidence, making them insufficient to confirm the existence of such a feature.

supporting.text: ATM software is primarily designed for transaction processing and fraud detection, not for interpreting reversed PIN entries as distress signals, as this would require additional, unverified functionality.

attacks.text: ATM software is primarily designed for transaction processing and fraud detection, not for interpreting reversed PIN entries as distress signals, as this would require additional, unverified functionality.

Such experimental implementations are extremely rare and not standardized across ATM networks, making them unreliable as a general security feature.
Fraud detection systems in ATMs already monitor for unusual patterns, so adding reversed-PIN detection would not require significant additional functionality.
Monitoring for reversed PINs specifically would require distinct programming logic from general pattern detection, increasing system complexity and potential vulnerabilities.
